text:
In some situatons, two characters of an SSI-included file get dropped. It happens when the user-agent does a GET with HTTP/1.1
It seems to not happen with HTTP/1.0 
I believe this is an apache bug. This error happens in httpd 2.0.42 and 2.0.43
it does not happen in 2.0.39 or 2.0.40 This server currently is running:
Apache/2.0.43 (Unix)
creator: www@csua.berkeley.edu
trawick@apache.org
text:
How many characters?  Which characters?  Can you show your SSI directive
as well as an indication (error_log record perhaps) of what Apache was
trying to use?

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
Upon rereading my update I see I misunderstood your report.  I was hoping
that this was a recently-fixed issue where a character at the end of a URL
name was lost, but you're clearly talking about the contents of the file.

Beyond the use of HTTP/1.1, does it only fail when the client issues more
than one request on the same TCP connection?

By any chance can you construct a simple testcase?

creator: www@csua.berkeley.edu
text:
The testcase URL is:
http://csua.berkeley.edu:8088/test/includes.shtml

I believe it also fails when two requests
are made on the same connection.

thanks a bunch for the testcase...  hopefully we can get this problem
resolved soon...

how mod_include represents the SSI-parsed result.

I have seen a couple of bugs in regards to this, and they ALL the reporters seem

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
Please ask reporters if they are using binary builds of Apache.  Because
  we do all of our testing for bogus sendfile() behaviors based on the BUILD
  machine's kernel level, we are probably distributing binaries that are
  bogus for some (or many) users.

creator: www@csua.berkeley.edu
